philosophy.title: Coaching Philosophy
philosophy.subtitle: My approach to football development
philosophy.coreIntro: My coaching philosophy is based on a developmental, humanistic and demanding approach, where the player is seen and developed in an integrated way: technical, tactical, physical, psychological, social and human.

learningEnvironment.title: Learning Environment
learningEnvironment.text: I believe that football should primarily be a learning environment, where players are encouraged to think, decide, make mistakes, correct them and grow. Mistakes are a natural and essential part of the learning process, as long as there is proper guidance, feedback and a safe environment.

trainingMethodology.title: Training Methodology
trainingMethodology.text: I aim to create challenging, dynamic and game-realistic training contexts, based on the Portuguese training methodology and the principles of Tactical Periodization, where the game is the central reference of the entire process. Training is structured according to the team's Game Model and the individual characteristics of each player.

integratedTraining.title: Integrated Training
integratedTraining.text: I place great importance on integrated training, where technical, tactical, physical and cognitive contents are developed together and always linked to decision-making.

playingStyle.title: Playing Style
playingStyle.text: I support a proactive style of play, with a clear intention to have possession, build from the back in an organized way, create superiorities, encourage mobility, creativity and positive aggressiveness in attack, while never neglecting defensive balance, collective organization and quick reaction after losing the ball.

thePlayerAsAPerson.title: The Player as a Person
thePlayerAsAPerson.text: I see the player as a person before being an athlete. Therefore, I seek to know my players, understand their contexts, motivations, difficulties and adjust my approach to each profile. The coach–player relationship must be based on trust, clear communication and consistency.

theTeam.title: The Team
theTeam.text: I believe in the collective strength of the team above all else. Success is built on synchronized effort, mutual trust and shared objectives. Every player has a defined role, and every role serves the team's game model. Individual talent is valued and developed, but it must always be placed at the service of the collective. A strong team culture, based on solidarity, accountability and a common identity, is the foundation for sustained competitive performance.

philosophy.coreValuesIntro: As a coach, I consider it essential to:
coreValuesList: Promote an environment of respect, discipline and responsibility
Develop autonomous, intelligent and confident players
Value the team above the individual
philosophy.corePersonal: I see the player as a person before being an athlete. Therefore, I seek to know my players, understand their contexts, motivations, difficulties and adjust my approach to each profile. The coach–player relationship must be based on trust, clear communication and consistency.
philosophy.coreProfessional: I am a coach who plans, observes, analyzes and constantly reflects on his work. I strongly believe in continuous education and openness to new ideas, always maintaining a critical and reflective mindset.
philosophy.coreClosing: Success is not measured only by immediate results, but mainly by the sustained development of players, the quality of their behaviors in the game and the ability to form better people through football.
philosophy.approachText: I lead training sessions with clarity, energy, and a clear sense of direction, ensuring every player understands their role while feeling motivated to improve. My sessions are well-structured, game-related and designed to replicate real match scenarios. I prioritize player development through a balance of technical, tactical, physical and psychological components, always adapting content to the age and level of the group.
approachPoints: Sessions led with clarity, energy and a clear sense of direction
Every player understands their role while feeling motivated to improve
Well-structured, game-related sessions designed to replicate real match scenarios
Player development through a balance of technical, tactical, physical and psychological components
Content always adapted to the age and level of the group
philosophy.rolesText: I have taken on multiple roles in football, including Head Coach, Assistant Coach, Scouter, Analyst, and Football Advisor, each contributing to my well-rounded understanding of the game.

gameMomentsDescriptions.offensiveOrg: In offensive organization, I aim to build a team that takes ownership of the game — but above all, knows what to do with the ball. Every action on the ball must have a purpose: to progress, to unbalance, to finish.
gameMomentsDescriptions.defensiveOrg: Defending is a collective act. I look for compact, aggressive and organized teams that know how to control the opponent without the ball. More than dropping deep and reacting, I want teams that dictate the defensive game.
gameMomentsDescriptions.offensiveTrans: When we win the ball, attack the opponent's goal. If there is an opportunity to progress quickly, we attack. If not, we reorganize and rebuild. Transitioning well means reading the context.
gameMomentsDescriptions.defensiveTrans: Losing the ball does not mean losing control. The team must react immediately. The objective is simple: prevent the opponent from thinking and progressing on the pitch.
gameMomentsDescriptions.setPieces: Set pieces are strategic moments of the game — corners, free kicks, throw-ins, goal kicks and penalties. I see set pieces as clear opportunities to gain competitive advantage.
gameMomentsDescriptions.creativity: Within a clear structure, there is space for freedom. I believe the player should feel comfortable to take risks, create and decide. Creativity is not imposed — it is empowered.

offensiveOrg: Circulation with intention, not just possession
Rational occupation of space, creating constant passing lines
Ability to alternate between build-up, interior and direct play
Patient when necessary, vertical when possible
defensiveOrg: Guide the opponent into less dangerous areas
Always defend with reference to the ball
offensiveTrans: Immediate recognition of space and advantage
Close support to the ball carrier
Attack if possible, reorganize if not
defensiveTrans: Recover or at minimum delay the opponent
Foul if necessary to stop progression
setPieces: Organization and detail in every routine
Corners, free kicks, throw-ins, goal kicks, penalties
creativity: I provide tools, principles and context
Then I let talent express itself
Freedom to take risks within structure
Creativity is not imposed — it is empowered
